topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack 1.0: Installing an NTP Server

body.p: This page provides detailed information on configuring the seed VM as a Network Time Protocol (NTP) server. NTP is a networking protocol for clock synchronization between computer systems. The undercloud and overcloud systems are configured as NTP clients during the installation process.
All the Helion servers use UTC as a time zone.
Note: NTP clients should use only stratum 2 and higher servers

section.title: Trouble synching
section.p: If your client (including your NTP server) has trouble syncing time you can try the following.

li.p: Sync system time with system clock:

codeblock.codeph: hwclock [--utc | --localtime] -s --hctosys (update system time based on hardware clock) hwclock [--utc | --localtime] -w --systohc (update hardware clock based on system time) hwclock [--utc | --localtime] --systz (update system time based on timezone)

li.p: Verify hardware clock time
Verify system time
If the times are still not synching, check if NTP ports are blocked

codeblock.codeph:
sudo apt-get install nmap
sudo nmap -p123 -sU -P0 <localhost | known ntp host>

section.title: Stratum lower than 10
section.p: NTP uses a hierarchical, semi-layered system of time sources. Each level of this hierarchy is termed a "stratum" and is assigned a number starting with zero at the top. The number represents the distance from the reference clock and is used to prevent cyclical dependencies in the hierarchy.
HPE Helion OpenStack uses stratum 10. If your NTP stratum is lower than 10, set up your host as the time source by fudging a stratum 10.
